comments.commentBody:
I say the grid looks like a circle of people giving the finger.

Interestingly enough, me (with barely any of dad's help) got the bottom half done first. (I still haven't cracked the top as I write this.

Being a camp counselor has been the most rewarding experience I have ever had. As I enter my junior year in college, more and more people tell me I should get an internship and leave camp in the past where it belongs. I feel hurt by these comments because they show that so many people do not value the hard work I do but I also want to laugh at people's ignorance when they imply that being a caregiver to stranger's children is of little significance and an undesirable skill (as opposed to an unpaid, boring internship).

I have experienced many, if not all, of the situations you wrote about in your blog. I know that my work at camp is intensely valuable and irreplaceable for the both the kids I work with and for myself. People who see my work and passion as insignificant do not understand the variable definition of fulfillment and work ethic. The people who tell me to leave camp would not be able to last a week as a counselor.

Your assumption that unpaid internships implies a connection through family or one's school is not correct. There are many college students and grads who have sought internships completely on their own in order to receive experience and connections in a field they wish to pursue after school. I got my first internship (summer of my sophomore year) by writing to the company about what I had long admired about their work and wanted to learn from an internship with them. Since then, I have held several internships in the same field not because I feel "entitled" in any way but because I am ambitious, eager and focused.

I understand your support of the author's daughter in choosing a paid job with lots of responsibility. Please don't knock those who choose to take unpaid internships as "whiny" or "entitled" because they genuinely believe it will help them move forward in their chosen field.

Nothing will cleanse the horror of the 2006 NLCS loss to the Cardinals and the final called strike to Beltran.

Every Met fan in the world would trade this tainted no-hitter for Beltran swinging at that 2006 NLCS pitch instead of leaving it on his shoulder.

The Mets cleansed three ghosts of 2006 tonight in one very amazing game. They beat Adam Wainwright, the man who whiffed Beltran to win game 7. Baxter's catch of Molina's shot to left, the man who beat them in the ninth, and Beltran's not so foul foul ball. Imagine if it was Molina or Beltran who broke up the no hitter.  And of course, the first no hitter in every Mets fans' lifetime. A lot of good karma tonight.
Amazin!!!

Stunning! Congrats to Johan, the Mets and all of the Metropolitan fans!

Lifelong Mets Fan

P.S. OK, but please make sure to sign David Wright to a very long term contract.

@deo

Good one. I borrowed some of your steps

TADPOLE
PAROLED
PAROLE
PROLE
ROLE
GOER
FROG
The whole world should use pidgen and everyone should only wear black and white right?

This is not sentimental. There is so much literature and spiritual wisdom in Indian languages that will become inaccessible to these people due to their ignorance and laziness. How will one ever overcome that? How will one enjoy a translated poetry? If we were to use your utilitarian logic, then lets do away with all different dressing styles, food recipes, music etc.
Civilization started in these tropical places you imbecile. Egypt, Iraq, India, China etc were all in the warmer latitudes. Me thinks your NYC education has prevented your development.

Been a Mets fan since I could follow baseball, circa 1964. For years, my kids have been watching me watch Mets games, and every night, there has been a moment for me to utter the phrase "and tonight is not the night." Well, tonight WAS the night, and I've got to admit, I never thought I'd live to see the day.
Maybe Adrian Johnson's blown call in the sixth is simply payback for Tom Seaver being denied in the ninth by Jimmy Qualls or Leron Lee. (Off topic, but did you see the pick of that ball by the ballboy about a nanosecond after Johnson made the call? And why did Oquendo and Matheny not argue until a few pitches later? Bizarre)
But this is the way it had to be, with Whitestone native Mike Baxter running into the wall to catch the Molina drive in the seventh. With Santana's pitch count elevating, when Terry Collins went out to see Johan in the eighth, I thought of what Johnny Keane said about leaving young Bob Gibson in the game to finish the Yankees dynasty in Game 7 of the 64 World Series: "I had a commitment to his heart." Truly applies to Johan as well.
Not only do I feel great for Johan and the entire Mets team, but I'm also happy for Gary Cohen and Howie Rose, who go back as far as I do, and who probably also never thought that they'd live to see the day...

What is horribly sad is watching the Keeping up with the Kardashian Tragedy unfold.  This man was once a hero and has been publicly, week after week, stripped of his manhood by his wife and step-daughers. Now wearing earrings and has no control or authority with this family. I couldn't watch this show watching Bruce decline into some kind of wimpering idiot.

Bruce Jenner 1976 Olympic Gold Medalist America’s Bi-centennial Decathlon World Champion 62 year’s young congratulations World’s Greatest Athlete, NBC Outstanding International Sportscaster of the Year, Olympic Commentator. World’s Greatest Dad proud father of ten children, humanitarian, actor author and producer we respect your accomplishments as America’s Finest Individual bravo and mahalo. Kauaicr07

I am happy to see Loyola win this game. Not just because I know someone on the team, either. This team was undervalued, as the author details, all along the way. It's good to see other teams in the hunt for the title, not just the usual suspects. Big ups to Pat Byrnes!

With a stigma of manipulating the second count to facilitate a second entry of George Bush to the White House already on it if, Florida further restricts democratic participation of people, specially the minorities and the groups feared of particular political leanings, not only would it  weaken the fabric of democracy, but also sow the seeds of social distrust and dissensions in the country. For, the way to power in a democratic system paves only through continuing empowerment of people, winning their trust, and not by putting hurdles in that path. Democracy, like tender plants, always flourishes in open space, not in dark shadows of distrust and revenge, that ultimately produce the greenhouse effects, not congenial for any growth.

Those who claim voter fraud (Karl Rove lesson #1: project your own iniquities onto your opponent.) are not trying to rig elections. They have rigged elections, as you point out. They continue to rig elections. There will be many attempts to fix this coming election. And if people who truly love democracy do nothing, the coming election will be fixed and a fraud.

I told people in 2000 we'd had a coup d'etat. I was told I was a kook. I would happily be found crazy, and learn I was delusional. But I suspect I have nothing to be happy about.

First I am not stoking class war, it's been being waged by the wealthy right for several decades already. As Warren Buffet has pointed out, and as he said, "my class is winning" Second, Australia has mandatory voting with 99% complience. It's not a lefty fantasy, it's what it should be. Everyone should be required to vote, I don't care if they vote for none of the above. The participation in democracy is central to its success in everyone being treated equally with dignity and respect. Gotta love it when conservatives still can't get facts straight. LOL

Voting is mandatory in Brasil, a country with 180 million people. Voting is done electronically, and the winner is declared the next day. If you do not vote, your CPF and passport is blocked. (CPF is a social security,national id )
You cannot purchase anything and you cannot travel. And you must pay a fine to remove the block. Voting is on a Sunday, so no work time is missed.
And now they have the first woman ever elected, Dilma Roussof, who by many accounts is doing a very nice job leading Brasil into the future.

Can this EVER happen in America? Nah!

Voter fraud is not our problem in the United States, manipulation of votes is our problem as witnessed in Ohio in 2004 and Flordia in 2000.  Very odd that those who claim voter fraud are the one perpetuating cheating in our national elections in trying to rig them to their favor. If the United States ever had mandatory voting laws, the republicans would not get elected nationally to 100 seats in the house and not even 25 in the Senate. If everyone voted. That is the conservatives biggest fear, large voter turnout. The time has arrived and should continue, Attorney General Eric Holder should issue a cease and desist order to all states, that no voters shall be purged without due hearings first, not purged first  as ineligable   the republicans wish to start class war that they already have and deny, go right ahead and try to destroy the voting base of the U.S. and see the backlash.

Great minds think alike Gail. I thought the exact same thing. John Edwards redemption will be committing himself and his legal expertise into helping the poor, underprivilaged, through a legal foundation. You are perfect in your assessment. Bravo!

While I started from the top with SRIS and ACTING, I ran into every possible miscue.  But I loved the 15s.  Great clues and traps.  I loved the chain unit clues, tho I was sure that a dept. store belonged there somewhere.  Diamond Jim was a surprise; never knew about his car.  MOSSY as conservative...that I don't get.  All in all...IT'S NO COMPARISON with yesterday.
"The poor" were probably in the ambulance he was chasing.

Actually from a veracity standpoint I see no particular difference between Edwards and Romney except of course Edwards has/had a documented mistress. I really do not know the status of Romney with regard to wives or mistresses. I still wonder whether there were to many women in the car when the dog was on the roof. That being said, the column is spot on.

Congrats, Johan......such a class act. I remember Tom Terrific calling Johan the pitcher who would do it!
Hats off to the whole team
It had to end sometime. Glad it was Johan, a pitcher and a man to look up to. Terrific night for Mets fans, and yes, I use that adjective with all due respect. LGM!

Sour grapes. It was a ball hit at 100 MPH, with a sidespin slice. Should he have made the call? Yes. But baseball is full of umpiring mistakes, as the speed at MLB level is very fast, and human eyes are not cameras. Give Johan his due. There are many no-hitters that have had worse calls--no umpire wants to make a mistake like the Galaraga game. There have plenty incidents of charity called strikes, and scorers who have ruled hits as errors.

This guy sounds like a Bronx frontrunner.
Deadline... Great poem!  Your Muse is sublime.

Perhaps admirable. But my own gut never stopped wondering how staged his poverty platform was. That doubt will continue, unless as Ms. Collins suggests, we never see or hear from his face again in the media.
This probably contributed to why he was prosecuted instead of Wall Street barons.

But what has HE ever done to help the poor?  I fear he used the need to help the poor as a line/angle to help his own campaign and nothing more.  Since he left the campaign, what has he DONE to give any evidence that God has a plan for him? He might think that God is not through with him, but I am!

There is still something to be said for John Edwards, and I say this with sincerity: he was the only major candidate in recent times to have emphasized the need to help the poor.  I still admire him for that stand.
